headline: Good starting point for relocation, good end stop before finising the career, boring for senior devs
pros:
- a lot of space for self-improvement
- flat hierarchy inside KPN
- modern technology stack
- great pension options
- quite high salary for medior-level devs
- work/life balance is not that balanced and actually "life" part has bigger focus here.
cons:
- technical debt is not addressed that well and is constantly piling up
- backend services architecture is not being reviewed by anyone, sometimes decisions about it are being made by management
- a lot of integrations with third-party services, sometimes it is completely unclear who is responsible for what
- no so high rates for experienced developers
- work/life balance is not that balanced and actually "life" part has bigger focus here, sometimes it was really annoying that people leave as soon as it is their time to leave without finishing simple task we were working in pair
- processes sometimes seem to be more important than achieving actual results, though they are not that enforced, so team still have freedom to work in a way they prefer
- not so much technical challenges for senior devs

headline: Good place to work. Very nice peopel.
pros:
I enjoyed my time at KPN. It's a friendly environment, they care about you and your development. Management is open to feedbacks and tries to improve things.

It worth mentioning that I worked at the Amsterdam office (KPN Technium), and as I know from feedbacks other work locations can be quite different.
cons: The Tech stack can be quite old, and some architectural decisions can be reasonably justified. Slow in progress, and not everyone tries to improve things.

headline: Do not join if you are an expat working in IT
pros:
good pay and benefits
flexible schedule and good work-life balance
technologies used within the Managed Hybrid Cloud are new and in high-demand (Docker, Kubernetes, Terraform,etc )
cons:
everything is in Dutch; I even sent e-mails to colleagues asking something in English and getting a reply in Dutch. I've been in meetings where they held the meeting in Dutch even though everybody knew I did not speak Dutch. Literally got up and left because of this. If you work in IT you can find a lot of international companies in Amsterdam that are way better than this and treat their employees with respect.

People expect you to go and ask questions, nobody really explains anything or gives you a perspective towards the project(s), their history and meaning. There is no top-down integrated vision and top management never connects with employees. Communication is very bad all-around.
Management is totally disconnected from the engineering teams, at least where I was working (Managed Hybrid Cloud)
the building in Amsterdam is crap, old, cold in the winter, hot in the summer.

headline: It's a nice company to work for

headline: nice place to work
pros: Good possibilities to develop yourself, very good place to learn a lot in a short amount of time. Nice culture, enthusiastic people with passion for their products. Nice working environment, flat organization.

headline: Good employer
pros: Offer regular sales and communications training. Inventive structure with bonus payments. Good team collaboration. Overall managers are engaged and realistic in their expectations.
cons: Applies to all retail: working on weekends, sometimes evenings. Closing duties can take longer and are not paid. Lot depends on the store manager and team. Some sores' individual conversion targets are less realistic than others.

headline: Sap basis
pros: Great working environment and professional coworkers
cons: No cons at all, it's a great company

pros: Combination of IT and Telco services makes it special. Has lots of potential with well educated work force and high quality services. Flexible employer with great products and services. Values the environment (green) and values society (lonely elderly and sick children who are not able to go to school). Currently in transition from product/services oriented to a customer oriented company which is great. Not clear how fast company is able to make this transition.
cons: Being market leader full of challengers in a declining market is tough. Need to be more able to adapt to changes. Also procedures and processes make it a challenge to act fast and deliver.

headline: High on individual smartness, low on group agility.
pros: A smaller players in the European Telecoms market, with excellent potential to be a smart follower. Potential of surprisingly clever products and innovations with high impact agility. Understood content before it becoming a fashionable statement. Capex leverage through Asian suppliers.
cons: Lack of long term (holistic) vision. Deep rooted cultural symptoms of an incumbent / state owned monopoly. Resulting in constant deadlocks and risk averse decision making process. Customer base too small to leverage in procurement.

It is not easy to cooperate with colleagues, if they see an opportunity to fulfill a clients need with their solution at the expense of the client needs it will happen.

headline: Paying the price for lack of investments in the past

*Good people, personally motivated.
*Strong (leading) presence in markets it operates in.
*Good working conditions, especially work/life balance and working from home.
*Excellent marketing.
cons:
*Lack of strategy and investment result in lagging portfolio and IT.
*Continuous reorganizations have led to lacking commitment of workforce.
*Highly centralized organization result in long decision cycles and compromised choices.
*Current board is lacking in long term vision and strategy.
